title: Would the universe collapse to singularity, if for some reason it stops expanding? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are theoretical reasons to believe the universe is powered by expansion - as I and others have shown, the gravitational attraction created by masses is the result of the expansion factor 4(pi)G. This term happens to have a value that very closely approximates Einstein’s Cosmological Constant term “ Lambda x R/3” which has a present value in the range of c^/R. If the root cause of gravity is expansion, then w/o expansion, there would be no cause for collapse. It is probably safe to assume that expansion is intimately tied to the existence of a process that creates positive and negative energy equally, ergo, the universe must expand as it is intrinsically linked to factors that determine the existence of the universe. Regarding Expansion, Eddington had this to say: “The conception of the expanding universe seems to crown the edifice of physical science like a lofty pinnacle. I few years ago I became strongly convinced that in these astronomical discoveries in the remoteness of space, we had picked up the key to the mysteries of the proton and electron ….” Incidentally, there is a force predictive model of the electron based upon cosmological expansion.

No. Even under General Relativity, the Universe should be infinite, homogenous and because of that would never collapse into a point. Mathematicians will say that this solution is unstable.
